info.title: Statement of Work
info.subtitle: METS/ALTO Production for Phase I of the Blue Mountain Project

abstract.para: The Statement of Work agreement between Princeton University Library (PUL) and Digital Divide Data (DDD) for the remaining portion of the Blue Mountain Project, Phase I. It supercedes all prior statements of work and production schedules, whether produced by DDD or by PUL, in whatever form.

sect1.title: Rationale
sect1.para: The total page count for Blue Mountain, Phase I is approximately 92,305. The grant cycle for Phase I ends on September 1, 2014, and production should be completed well before then. The following schedule, then, is based on 7 two-month production cycles for Digital Divide Data, where a cycle is defined in the plan of work below.

sect1.title: Reference Documents
sect1.para: The Blue Mountain Project has detailed its policies, requirements, and formats in a series of reference documents maintained and distributed on the Blue Mountain wiki at the Blue Mountain Project's GitHub portal https://github.com/pulibrary/BlueMountain.

sect1.title: Plan of Work
sect1.para: The Work shall be divided into discrete units (hereafter referred to as batches, deliveries, or tranches), as defined in the section below. Processing of each unit shall follow this procedure:

step.para: For each unit, PUL shall provide DDD with the following items:

formalpara.title: LZW-Compressed TIFF Files
formalpara.para:
For each title, PUL shall provide image files in the format specified in the reference document. PUL shall arrange these image files into systems of directories (folders) organized by date of publication, as specified in the reference document. Princeton shall make every reasonable effort to ensure these issue sets are accurate and complete. If, upon DDD's inspection at receipt, there are missing pages, duplicate pages, or other directory-level or file-level anomalies which impede or otherwise interfere with DDD's subsequent processing of the materials, DDD shall inform Princeton immediately for remedy. Princeton shall not be responsible for redundant work performed by DDD in remedy of such anomalies. These page-image files shall be delivered via one of two media, subject to negotiation:
File transfer via FTP. This is preferred. Princeton shall provide an FTP portal for this purpose.
Portable hard drive, shipped to DDD in Cambodia via FedEx. If the hard drive option is chosen, DDD will absorb the cost of shipping.

formalpara.title: Title-Specific Markup Policies
Descriptive Metadata for each Issue
formalpara.para: PUL shall prepare provide title, volume and issue numbers and labels, dates of publication, and the identifiers required by Blue Mountain as described in the reference documentation. PUL will deliver this metadata in MODS format, as described in the reference documentation (The Metadata Store). PUL will maintain the metadata store in the Blue Mountain Github repository; DDD shall be responsible for retrieving these files from the Blue Mountain GitHub repository and for updating their local copies should changes become necessary after production of a batch begins.

step.para: DDD shall process the page images and descriptive metadata into METS/ALTO, JPEG2000, and PDF outputs (the PRODUCT) according to the Blue Mountain docWorks configuration.
DDD shall deliver the Product to Princeton via one of the authorized transmission media, as specified above.

DDD shall issue an invoice to Princeton for EXACTLY the work performed in fulfillment of this batch. The Blue Mountain Project will not accept invoices that fail to specify, in detail, the work being billed, or that bill for work that spans discrete batches, or that entail work done for other Princeton-related projects.

Princeton shall ingest the Product into its content-management system and the Veridian content-delivery system. Princeton shall evaluate the Product, in its raw form and in its deployed form, and shall notify DDD in a timely fashion of any anomalies outside the tolerances set forth below.
Princeton shall have 30 days to request corrections. At the end of 30 days, Princeton shall either (a) accept the work and pay the invoice; or (b) reject the work and delete it from its systems.

sect1.title: Schedule of Work
sect1.para: The schedule shall be maintained as a set of milestones in the Project's Goplan tracking system.

All identifiers are present and accurate.
The MODS descriptive metadata meets the specifications detailed in the reference document.

The logical and physical structMap elements are consistent with the docWorks configuration AND conform with the specifications outlined in the reference document and any markup policies agreed to by both parties.

All image derivatives conform with the specifications detailed in the reference document.
All PDF derivatives conform with the specifications detailed in the reference document.
All file names, directory names, and general organization of files as delivered conform with the specifications detailed in the reference document.

Headlines and bylines will be 99.95% free of significant errors.

sect2.title: Quality Evaluation Guidelines
sect2.para: When DDD has completed a batch, it shall submit output to Princeton for ingestion into Princeton's Veridian installation.
Upon receipt of a batch, Princeton will have 30 days to accept or reject it. Princeton will employ the following procedures to evaluate a batch.

step.title: Evaluation of Zoning and Segmentation
step.para: Princeton will examine five (5) issues for zoning and segmentation errors. A zoning or segmentation error shall be identified using the following criteria:

listitem.para: If an article is missing one or more zones, that shall count as an error.
If an article contains one or more zones that are not part of the article in the original, it shall be counted as an error.
If the sequence of zoned regions is not in the proper order, it shall count as an error.

sect2.para: Princeton will record the results of these examinations in its report. If significant errors are discovered, Princeton and DDD will confer.

step.para: Princeton will draw a random sample of 350 headlines from the batch and measure their accuracy by comparing each headline with its original and recording all significant errors. The accuracy rate of the sample should meet or exceed 99.95%.
Princeton will examine the fifth article in every sample (as above) for errors in the body text, counting the number of significant errors that occur, where significance is as defined above.
We shall assume an average article length of 500 words. For an accuracy rate of 90% or better an article should therefore contain no more than 50 significant errors.
Princeton and DDD shall agree that if more than 5% of the samples from a given batch fail, the batch is not acceptable.

Princeton will evaluate 1 random 2,000 character sampling of Issue Metadata. If the sample contains more than 1 error (i.e., it falls below 99.95%), the issue metadata fails and must be rechecked and resubmitted by DDD.
Princeton will not verify XML validity, as docWorks automatically validates the files it produces against the appropriate schemas.

listitem.para: Pricing for METS/ALTO processing is determined by the level of service set out in “Description of Work” above.
Exact costs for shipping will be determined by the project schedule and number of batches required.
This pricing is contingent upon the Library’s commitment to complete the project under one contract, in a timely manner based on our mutually agreed schedule. See “Schedule” for details.

sect1.title: Notes to Pricing
sect1.para: Client shall pay DDD all amounts due as provided above. Since the actual number of output characters, pages, records and the like may differ from the parties' best estimates made as of the date of this Agreement, it is understood and agreed the final Price due shall be based upon the actual amount of Work delivered to Client by DDD.

DDD shall have the right to change the Price if the input provided by Client differs materially from the sample(s) provided or the assumptions or estimates used by the parties. DDD will promptly give written notice of any such change to Client and may suspend Work until the change is approved in writing by Client.

listitem.para: Both DDD and Client agree that this Agreement commits them only to the Work outlined in this Agreement, and not to any additional work.
Client shall be responsible to pay for any sales, use or other taxes due as a result of this Agreement or the Work.
This Agreement shall be governed and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of New York.

Neither party shall be liable for any delay or default in the performance of this Agreement if such delay is due to Acts of God or acts of war, insurrections, riots, fires, explosions, governmental order or regulation or other causes reasonably beyond the control of the parties. In the event of such delay, the parties agree to promptly discuss the appropriate steps to be taken as the result of such delay.
DDD agrees to promptly correct any defects or mistakes that it makes in the Work at no charge to Client for a period of sixty (60) days following the completion of the Work.

DDD shall be responsible for loss or damage to any of Client’s property which is caused by DDD; provided, however, in no event shall DDD's liability under this Agreement or in any way connected with the Work exceed the Price paid by Client to DDD for the Work pursuant to this Agreement.

sect1.title: Representation and Warranties
sect1.para: Client represents and warrants the following:

listitem.para: Client owns the copyright or has permission to copy any data or materials ("Materials") that it submits for Servicing;
The Materials are not unlawful, threatening, abusive, defamatory, obscene or invade another person's privacy or further the commission or concealment of a crime;
Client is lawfully authorized to transmit the Materials; and

The Materials are not the subject of, or infringe upon, any patent, trademark, trade name, trade secret, copyright, right of publicity, moral right or other intellectual property right of another person or entity.

sect1.title: Mediation and Arbitration
sect1.para: In the event of a dispute under this Agreement, the parties agree to submit such dispute to non-binding mediation and to use their best efforts in resolving such a dispute through mediation. In the event the parties are unable to resolve such a dispute through mediation, then such dispute or other controversy arising under or in connection with this Agreement shall be settled exclusively by Arbitration conducted before an Arbitrator in accordance with the rules of the American Arbitration Association then in effect. Said Arbitration shall be held in New York, New York. The decision of the Arbitrator shall be final and binding on both parties and their heirs and legal representatives. Judgment may be entered upon the Arbitrator’s award in any court located in New York, New York. Each party shall be responsible to pay for its own costs in connection with the Arbitration and the parties shall bear the costs of Arbitration itself and the mediation in equal shares.

sect1.title: Successors and Assigns
sect1.para: The parties agree that this Agreement shall be binding upon and inure to the benefit of each of the parties hereto and their successors and assigns.

sect1.title: Cooperation
sect1.para: Each party hereto agrees to cooperate with the other in carrying out the terms of this Agreement. In connection therewith, each party agrees to execute such documents and take such steps as may be necessary or advisable to carry out the purposes of this Agreement, whether before or after the date of this Agreement.
